column2: Then out of the bushes came three Beast People, with hunched shoulders, protruding heads, misshapen hands awkwardly held, and inquisitive, unfriendly eyes and advanced towards me with hesitating gestures.
column3: Then out of the bushes came three Beast People, with hunched shoulders, protruding heads, misshapen hands awkwardly held, and inquisitive, unfriendly eyes and advanced towards me with hesitating gestures.

column2: XX.
column3: x x.

column2: ALONE WITH THE BEAST FOLK.
column3: ALONE WITH THE BEAST FOLK.

column2: I FACED these people, facing my fate in them, single-handed now,--literally single-handed, for I had a broken arm.
column3: I FACED these people, facing my fate in them, single handed now,--literally single handed, for I had a broken arm.

column2: In my pocket was a revolver with two empty chambers.
column3: In my pocket was a revolver with two empty chambers.

column2: Among the chips scattered about the beach lay the two axes that had been used to chop up the boats. The tide was creeping in behind me.
column3: Among the chips scattered about the beach lay the two axes that had been used to chop up the boats. The tide was creeping in behind me.

column2: There was nothing for it but courage.
column3: There was nothing for it but courage.

column2: I looked squarely into the faces of the advancing monsters. They avoided my eyes, and their quivering nostrils investigated the bodies that lay beyond me on the beach.
column3: I looked squarely into the faces of the advancing monsters. They avoided my eyes, and their quivering nostrils investigated the bodies that lay beyond me on the beach.

column2: I took half-a-dozen steps, picked up the blood-stained whip that lay beneath the body of the Wolf-man, and cracked it.
column3: I took half a dozen steps, picked up the blood stained whip that lay beneath the body of the Wolf man, and cracked it.

column2: They stopped and stared at me.
column3: They stopped and stared at me.

column2: Salute! said I. "Bow down!"
column3: Salute! said i "Bow down!"

column2: They hesitated.
column3: They hesitated.

column2: One bent his knees.
column3: One bent his knees.

column2: I repeated my command, with my heart in my mouth, and advanced upon them.
column3: I repeated my command, with my heart in my mouth, and advanced upon them.

column2: One knelt, then the other two.
column3: One knelt, then the other two.

column2: I turned and walked towards the dead bodies, keeping my face towards the three kneeling Beast Men, very much as an actor passing up the stage faces the audience.
column3: I turned and walked towards the dead bodies, keeping my face towards the three kneeling Beast Men, very much as an actor passing up the stage faces the audience.

column2: They broke the Law, said I, putting my foot on the Sayer of the Law. "They have been slain,--even the Sayer of the Law; even the Other with the Whip.
column3: They broke the Law, said I, putting my foot on the Sayer of the Law. "They have been slain,--even the Sayer of the Law; even the Other with the Whip.

column2: Great is the Law!
column3: Great is the Law!

column2: Come and see."
column3: Come and see."

column2: None escape, said one of them, advancing and peering.
column3: None escape, said one of them, advancing and peering.

column2: None escape, said I. "Therefore hear and do as I command." They stood up, looking questioningly at one another.
column3: None escape, said i "Therefore hear and do as I command." They stood up, looking questioningly at one another.

column2: Stand there, said I.
column3: Stand there, said i

column2: I picked up the hatchets and swung them by their heads from the sling of my arm; turned Montgomery over; picked up his revolver still loaded in two chambers, and bending down to rummage, found half-a-dozen cartridges in his pocket.
column3: I picked up the hatchets and swung them by their heads from the sling of my arm; turned Montgomery over; picked up his revolver still loaded in two chambers, and bending down to rummage, found half a dozen cartridges in his pocket.

column2: Take him, said I, standing up again and pointing with the whip; "take him, and carry him out and cast him into the sea."
column3: Take him, said I, standing up again and pointing with the whip; "take him, and carry him out and cast him into the sea."

column2: They came forward, evidently still afraid of Montgomery, but still more afraid of my cracking red whip-lash; and after some fumbling and hesitation, some whip-cracking and shouting, they lifted him gingerly, carried him down to the beach, and went splashing into the dazzling welter of the sea.
column3: They came forward, evidently still afraid of Montgomery, but still more afraid of my cracking red whip lash; and after some fumbling and hesitation, some whip cracking and shouting, they lifted him gingerly, carried him down to the beach, and went splashing into the dazzling welter of the sea.

column2: On! said I, "on!
column3: On! said I, "on!

column2: Carry him far."
column3: Carry him far."

column2: They went in up to their armpits and stood regarding me.
column3: They went in up to their armpits and stood regarding me.

column2: Let go, said I; and the body of Montgomery vanished with a splash. Something seemed to tighten across my chest.
column3: Let go, said I; and the body of Montgomery vanished with a splash. Something seemed to tighten across my chest.

column2: Good! said I, with a break in my voice; and they came back, hurrying and fearful, to the margin of the water, leaving long wakes of black in the silver.
column3: Good! said I, with a break in my voice; and they came back, hurrying and fearful, to the margin of the water, leaving long wakes of black in the silver.

column2: At the water's edge they stopped, turning and glaring into the sea as though they presently expected Montgomery to arise therefrom and exact vengeance.
column3: At the water's edge they stopped, turning and glaring into the sea as though they presently expected Montgomery to arise therefrom and exact vengeance.

column2: Now these, said I, pointing to the other bodies.
column3: Now these, said I, pointing to the other bodies.

column2: They took care not to approach the place where they had thrown Montgomery into the water, but instead, carried the four dead Beast People slantingly along the beach for perhaps a hundred yards before they waded out and cast them away.
column3: They took care not to approach the place where they had thrown Montgomery into the water, but instead, carried the four dead Beast People slantingly along the beach for perhaps a hundred yards before they waded out and cast them away.

column2: As I watched them disposing of the mangled remains of M'ling, I heard a light footfall behind me, and turning quickly saw the big Hyena-swine perhaps a dozen yards away.
column3: As I watched them disposing of the mangled remains of M'ling, I heard a light footfall behind me, and turning quickly saw the big Hyena swine perhaps a dozen yards away.

column2: His head was bent down, his bright eyes were fixed upon me, his stumpy hands clenched and held close by his side.
column3: His head was bent down, his bright eyes were fixed upon me, his stumpy hands clenched and held close by his side.

column2: He stopped in this crouching attitude when I turned, his eyes a little averted.
column3: He stopped in this crouching attitude when I turned, his eyes a little averted.

column2: For a moment we stood eye to eye.
column3: For a moment we stood eye to eye.

column2: I dropped the whip and snatched at the pistol in my pocket; for I meant to kill this brute, the most formidable of any left now upon the island, at the first excuse. It may seem treacherous, but so I was resolved.
column3: I dropped the whip and snatched at the pistol in my pocket; for I meant to kill this brute, the most formidable of any left now upon the island, at the first excuse. It may seem treacherous, but so I was resolved.

column2: I was far more afraid of him than of any other two of the Beast Folk. His continued life was I knew a threat against mine.
column3: I was far more afraid of him than of any other two of the Beast Folk. His continued life was I knew a threat against mine.

column2: I was perhaps a dozen seconds collecting myself.
column3: I was perhaps a dozen seconds collecting myself.

column2: Then cried I, "Salute! Bow down!"
column3: Then cried I, "Salute! Bow down!"

column2: His teeth flashed upon me in a snarl.
column3: His teeth flashed upon me in a snarl.

column2: Who are _you_ that I should--
column3: Who are underscore you underscore that I should-

column2: Perhaps a little too spasmodically I drew my revolver, aimed quickly and fired.
column3: Perhaps a little too spasmodically I drew my revolver, aimed quickly and fired.

column2: I heard him yelp, saw him run sideways and turn, knew I had missed, and clicked back the cock with my thumb for the next shot. But he was already running headlong, jumping from side to side, and I dared not risk another miss.
column3: I heard him yelp, saw him run sideways and turn, knew I had missed, and clicked back the cock with my thumb for the next shot. But he was already running headlong, jumping from side to side, and I dared not risk another miss.

column2: Every now and then he looked back at me over his shoulder.
column3: Every now and then he looked back at me over his shoulder.

column2: He went slanting along the beach, and vanished beneath the driving masses of dense smoke that were still pouring out from the burning enclosure.
column3: He went slanting along the beach, and vanished beneath the driving masses of dense smoke that were still pouring out from the burning enclosure.

column2: For some time I stood staring after him.
column3: For some time I stood staring after him.

column2: I turned to my three obedient Beast Folk again and signalled them to drop the body they still carried. Then I went back to the place by the fire where the bodies had fallen and kicked the sand until all the brown blood-stains were absorbed and hidden.
column3: I turned to my three obedient Beast Folk again and signalled them to drop the body they still carried. Then I went back to the place by the fire where the bodies had fallen and kicked the sand until all the brown blood stains were absorbed and hidden.

column2: I dismissed my three serfs with a wave of the hand, and went up the beach into the thickets.
column3: I dismissed my three serfs with a wave of the hand, and went up the beach into the thickets.

column2: I carried my pistol in my hand, my whip thrust with the hatchets in the sling of my arm. I was anxious to be alone, to think out the position in which I was now placed.
column3: I carried my pistol in my hand, my whip thrust with the hatchets in the sling of my arm. I was anxious to be alone, to think out the position in which I was now placed.

column2: A dreadful thing that I was only beginning to realise was, that over all this island there was now no safe place where I could be alone and secure to rest or sleep. I had recovered strength amazingly since my landing, but I was still inclined to be nervous and to break down under any great stress. I felt that I ought to cross the island and establish myself with the Beast People, and make myself secure in their confidence. But my heart failed me.
column3: A dreadful thing that I was only beginning to realise was, that over all this island there was now no safe place where I could be alone and secure to rest or sleep. I had recovered strength amazingly since my landing, but I was still inclined to be nervous and to break down under any great stress. I felt that I ought to cross the island and establish myself with the Beast People, and make myself secure in their confidence. But my heart failed me.

column2: I went back to the beach, and turning eastward past the burning enclosure, made for a point where a shallow spit of coral sand ran out towards the reef.
column3: I went back to the beach, and turning eastward past the burning enclosure, made for a point where a shallow spit of coral sand ran out towards the reef.

column2: Here I could sit down and think, my back to the sea and my face against any surprise. And there I sat, chin on knees, the sun beating down upon my head and unspeakable dread in my mind, plotting how I could live on against the hour of my rescue (if ever rescue came).
column3: Here I could sit down and think, my back to the sea and my face against any surprise. And there I sat, chin on knees, the sun beating down upon my head and unspeakable dread in my mind, plotting how I could live on against the hour of my rescue (if ever rescue came).

column2: I tried to review the whole situation as calmly as I could, but it was difficult to clear the thing of emotion.
column3: I tried to review the whole situation as calmly as I could, but it was difficult to clear the thing of emotion.

column2: I began turning over in my mind the reason of Montgomery's despair. "They will change," he said; "they are sure to change." And Moreau, what was it that Moreau had said?
column3: I began turning over in my mind the reason of Montgomery's despair. "They will change," he said; "they are sure to change." And Moreau, what was it that Moreau had said?

column2: The stubborn beast-flesh grows day by day back again. Then I came round to the Hyena-swine.
column3: The stubborn beast flesh grows day by day back again. Then I came round to the Hyena swine.

column2: I felt sure that if I did not kill that brute, he would kill me. The Sayer of the Law was dead: worse luck.
column3: I felt sure that if I did not kill that brute, he would kill me. The Sayer of the Law was dead: worse luck.

column2: They knew now that we of the Whips could be killed even as they themselves were killed. Were they peering at me already out of the green masses of ferns and palms over yonder, watching until I came within their spring? Were they plotting against me?
column3: They knew now that we of the Whips could be killed even as they themselves were killed. Were they peering at me already out of the green masses of ferns and palms over yonder, watching until I came within their spring? Were they plotting against me?

column2: What was the Hyena-swine telling them? My imagination was running away with me into a morass of unsubstantial fears.
column3: What was the Hyena swine telling them? My imagination was running away with me into a morass of unsubstantial fears.

column2: My thoughts were disturbed by a crying of sea-birds hurrying towards some black object that had been stranded by the waves on the beach near the enclosure.
column3: My thoughts were disturbed by a crying of sea birds hurrying towards some black object that had been stranded by the waves on the beach near the enclosure.

column2: I knew what that object was, but I had not the heart to go back and drive them off. I began walking along the beach in the opposite direction, designing to come round the eastward corner of the island and so approach the ravine of the huts, without traversing the possible ambuscades of the thickets.
column3: I knew what that object was, but I had not the heart to go back and drive them off. I began walking along the beach in the opposite direction, designing to come round the eastward corner of the island and so approach the ravine of the huts, without traversing the possible ambuscades of the thickets.

column2: Perhaps half a mile along the beach I became aware of one of my three Beast Folk advancing out of the landward bushes towards me.
column3: Perhaps half a mile along the beach I became aware of one of my three Beast Folk advancing out of the landward bushes towards me.

column2: I was now so nervous with my own imaginings that I immediately drew my revolver. Even the propitiatory gestures of the creature failed to disarm me. He hesitated as he approached.
column3: I was now so nervous with my own imaginings that I immediately drew my revolver. Even the propitiatory gestures of the creature failed to disarm me. He hesitated as he approached.

column2: Go away! cried I.
column3: Go away! cried i

column2: There was something very suggestive of a dog in the cringing attitude of the creature.
column3: There was something very suggestive of a dog in the cringing attitude of the creature.

column2: It retreated a little way, very like a dog being sent home, and stopped, looking at me imploringly with canine brown eyes.
column3: It retreated a little way, very like a dog being sent home, and stopped, looking at me imploringly with canine brown eyes.

column2: Go away, said I. "Do not come near me."
column3: Go away, said i "Do not come near me."

column2: May I not come near you? it said.
column3: May I not come near you? it said.

column2: No; go away, I insisted, and snapped my whip.
column3: No; go away, I insisted, and snapped my whip.

column2: Then putting my whip in my teeth, I stooped for a stone, and with that threat drove the creature away.
column3: Then putting my whip in my teeth, I stooped for a stone, and with that threat drove the creature away.

column2: So in solitude I came round by the ravine of the Beast People, and hiding among the weeds and reeds that separated this crevice from the sea I watched such of them as appeared, trying to judge from their gestures and appearance how the death of Moreau and Montgomery and the destruction of the House of Pain had affected them.
column3: So in solitude I came round by the ravine of the Beast People, and hiding among the weeds and reeds that separated this crevice from the sea I watched such of them as appeared, trying to judge from their gestures and appearance how the death of Moreau and Montgomery and the destruction of the House of Pain had affected them.

column2: I know now the folly of my cowardice. Had I kept my courage up to the level of the dawn, had I not allowed it to ebb away in solitary thought, I might have grasped the vacant sceptre of Moreau and ruled over the Beast People. As it was I lost the opportunity, and sank to the position of a mere leader among my fellows.
column3: I know now the folly of my cowardice. Had I kept my courage up to the level of the dawn, had I not allowed it to ebb away in solitary thought, I might have grasped the vacant sceptre of Moreau and ruled over the Beast People. As it was I lost the opportunity, and sank to the position of a mere leader among my fellows.

column2: Towards noon certain of them came and squatted basking in the hot sand. The imperious voices of hunger and thirst prevailed over my dread. I came out of the bushes, and, revolver in hand, walked down towards these seated figures.
column3: Towards noon certain of them came and squatted basking in the hot sand. The imperious voices of hunger and thirst prevailed over my dread. I came out of the bushes, and, revolver in hand, walked down towards these seated figures.

column2: One, a Wolf-woman, turned her head and stared at me, and then the others.
column3: One, a Wolf woman, turned her head and stared at me, and then the others.

column2: None attempted to rise or salute me. I felt too faint and weary to insist, and I let the moment pass.
column3: None attempted to rise or salute me. I felt too faint and weary to insist, and I let the moment pass.

column2: I want food, said I, almost apologetically, and drawing near.
column3: I want food, said I, almost apologetically, and drawing near.

column2: There is food in the huts, said an Ox-boar-man, drowsily, and looking away from me.
column3: There is food in the huts, said an Ox boar man, drowsily, and looking away from me.

column2: I passed them, and went down into the shadow and odours of the almost deserted ravine.
column3: I passed them, and went down into the shadow and odours of the almost deserted ravine.

column2: In an empty hut I feasted on some specked and half-decayed fruit; and then after I had propped some branches and sticks about the opening, and placed myself with my face towards it and my hand upon my revolver, the exhaustion of the last thirty hours claimed its own, and I fell into a light slumber, hoping that the flimsy barricade I had erected would cause sufficient noise in its removal to save me from surprise.
column3: In an empty hut I feasted on some specked and half decayed fruit; and then after I had propped some branches and sticks about the opening, and placed myself with my face towards it and my hand upon my revolver, the exhaustion of the last thirty hours claimed its own, and I fell into a light slumber, hoping that the flimsy barricade I had erected would cause sufficient noise in its removal to save me from surprise.
